newsitem.title: USA: US spot fuel oil prices mostly slip despite crude.
newsitem.headline: US spot fuel oil prices mostly slip despite crude.

text.p: U.S. spot fuel oil prices mostly fell slightly Friday despite another rally in crude, pressured by abundant supplies and mediocre demand though East Coast temperatures were expected to dip next week.

"The fundamentals for resid are not great. There's oil all over and a lot of tanks are full," said one cash trader, noting colder weather next week could spur better utility burns and help trim inventories.
In New York Harbor, physical one percent eased slightly to about $21.75 a barrel, with January one percent paper sold early at $21.15 and later at $21.50, up 50 cents with crude.
High sulphurs in New York were steady to down slightly, with 2.2 percent pegged a quarter lower at about $18.25.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour eased slightly to about the $22.75 level, traders said.
U.S. Gulf Coast one percent also was modestly lower at $18.50 or under, while three percent notionally was steady to up slightly at $15.75-16.00. No USG deals were reported.

Traders said USG refinery problems like Star's damaged H-oil unit in Louisiana and increased Latin American supplies could keep HSFO on the defensive for a while though prices seemed to have stabilized for now.

New York city gate weekend gas prices firmed five to 10 cents Friday to the $4.05-4.10/mmBtu area compared to NYH one percent resid at a $3.46/mmBtu equivalent. For January, New York gas traded at $1.80 over the screen, or about $5.40-5.50/mmBtu, well-above resid paper at a $3.41/mmBtu equivalent.
